text: NIGHTMARE MUSIC THEME begins as we FADE UP on a SERIES OF all CLOSE and teasing. -- A man's FEET, in shabby work shoes, stalking through a junk bin in a dark, fire-lit, ash- dusted place.  A huge BOILER ROOM is what it is, although we only glimpse it piecemeal. Then we SEE a MAN'S HAND, dirty and nail-bitten, reach INTO FRAME and pick up a piece of METAL. -- ANOTHER ANGLE as the HAND grabs a grimey WORKGLOVE and slashes at it with a straight razor, until its fingertips are off. -- CLOSE ON SAME HANDS dumping four fishing knives out of a filthy bag.  Their blades are thin, curved, gleaming sharp. -- MORE ANGLES, EVEN CLOSER.  We can HEAR the MAN's wheezing BREATHING, but we still haven't seen his face.  We never will.  We just SEE more metal being assembled with crude tools, into some sort of linkage -- a splayed, spidery sort of apparatus, against a background light of FIRE, and a deep rushing of STEAM and HEAVY, DARK ENERGY. -- And then we see this linkage attached to the glove. -- Then the BLADES attached to all of it. -- Then the MAN'S HAND slips into this glove-like apparatus, filling it out and transforming it into an awesome, deadly claw-hand with four razor/talons gleaming at its blackened fingertips.  Suddenly the HAND arches and STRIKES FORWARD, SLASHING THROUGH a DARK CANVAS, tearing it to shreds. 1.    EXT.  LOS ANGELES.  NIGHT.  (2nd Unit) A PULSATION OF LIGHT AND SHADOW.  MUSIC DROPS AWAY to a h RUSHING OF WIND and DISTANT SIRENS.  CAMERA RACKS INTO FO HIGH PANORAMA of the San Fernando Valley, its night sky l within by a strange GREENISH LIGHT.  TITLES BEGIN. CAMERA TILTS DOWN and ZOOMS SWIFTLY into the valley's web light.

TITLES CONTINUE as TINA GRAY, a strong girl of fifteen in night shift, moves towards us down a dark concrete corrid steps quicken as TITLES appear in the portion of frame sh free. A subliminal COLLAGE of SOUND threads in and out of the M Distant insane LAUGHTER.  Slamming iron DOORS.  A bleatin CRY.  A LAMB, white and blank-faced, skitters across her on into the dark.  No reason why it's there. Then another SOUND, much nearer -- the slithering SCRAPE something like  fingernails across slate.  It sets our teeth on edge, twists the MUSIC, and sends TINA running. 3.    INT.  BOILER ROOM. Suddenly TINA's a tiny figure running among huge boilers pipes and catwalks -- a shadowed forest of iron and stone stops, listening intently as the SOUND of tiny hooves sud turns into the rattle of DISTANT RAIN. Then she hears RIPPING FABRIC. Someone is shouldering behind a ragged screen of dirty ca approaching TINA. CLOSER ON THE CANVAS.  The long curved fingerblades sudde punch through, flashing in the firelight, and begin rippi through the thick fabric, as easily as scalpels through f They make a hideous, extended RIPPING SOUND. TINA rushes away, hands over her ears. ANOTHER ANGLE -- as the blinded girl stumbles backwards. the canvas flaps free.  The blades are gone.  The TITLES everything goes silent. CAMERA CIRCLES until TINA's looking right into our eyes. light from a nearby boiler pours through her thin night d leaving her naked and vulnerable.  Then a deep, ragged VO whispers at her as CAMERA CLOSES IN ON HER FACE.
One two, Freddie's coming for you...

TINA opens her mouth to scream but only a dry, yellow dus out.  And at that precise moment a huge shadowy MAN with red and yellow sweater and a weird hat pulled over his sc face lunges at her.  And it's  his fingers that are tipped with the long blades of steel, glinting in the boney light and the hulk the look of an otherworldly predator. TINA dodges away, her legs suddenly elephantine and slow. MAN seizes the trailing hem of her nightgown and hauls he The MUSIC shrieks as TINA manages to tear free -- the MAN after her with a hoarse SHOUT as we --
TINA convulses in bed with a SCREAM, looking around wildl Someone is KNOCKING on her door.
You okay, Tina?
TINA'S MOTHER sticks her head in with a worried look.  TI up and blows out a breath, groggy.
Just a dream, Ma... (more to herself) Damn dream, is all...
The woman, once attractive, ventures a step into the room hovers BACKGROUND.  TINA'S mother waves him away without shoving a strand of bleached hair from her eyes.  She app her daughter.
Some dream, judging from that.
She nods at TINA's nightshift. TINA looks down at her nightgown, only now aware of the c penetrating it from the room.  There are four long slashe middle, cleanly cut as if by scalpels.
(distant, annoyed) You coming back to the sack or what?
Hold your horses. (lower, to Tina as she stands to leave) You gotta cut your nails or stop that kind of dreaming, Tina.  One or the other.
The woman shuts the door behind her.  TINA looks back to nightgown.
(low) Oh, shit.
She suddenly snatches up the cross that hangs over her he face white as her sheet.
(singing) One two, Freddie's coming for you... Three four better lock your door Five six grab your crucifix...

FADE UP ON SHOT OF this large highschool and its crowds o STUDENTS.  FOREGROUND, TINA climbs out of a cherry-red 19 Cadillac convertible with two other students, best friend WILSON, and Nancy's boyfriend and owner of the car, GLEN FOREGROUND several GRADESCHOOLERS are playing jump-rope, old ditty they sing continues unbroken from TINA's bedroo
Seven eight, gonna stay up late! Nine ten -- never sleep again!

7.    MOVING ANGLE FAVORING NANCY.  She's a pretty girl i sweater, with an easy, athletic stride and the look of a leader.  GLEN, holding her hand, wears one of the school' football jerseys; a good-natured, bright kid.  Tina's in mid-conversation.
(referring to kids' song) That's what it reminded me of -- that old jump rope song. (shudders) Worst nightmare I ever had. You wouldn't believe it.
Nancy nods.
Matter of fact I had a bad dream last night myself...
TINA turns to NANCY, but before either can say more, ROD lean, Richard Gere sort in black leather and New Wave stu up with them and interupts.
(to Tina) Had a hardon this morning when I woke up, Tina.  Had your name written all over it.
Tina cracks her gum with a look of withering indifference
There's four letters in my name, Rod.  How could there be room on your joint for four letters?
The guy's stopped in his tracks.
Hey, up yours with a twirling lawn mower!
He cuts off across the lawn.
Rod says the sweetest things.
He's nuts about you.
Yeah, nuts.
TINA makes a face and rakes her fingernails across a tree passes.
(yawns) Anyway, I'm too tired to worry about the creep.  Couldn't get back to sleep at all. (beat) So what you dream?
Forget it, the point is,
every
body has nightmares once in a while. No biggy.
Next time you have one, just tell yourself that's just all it is, right while you're having it, y'know?  That's the trick. Once you do that, you wake right up.  At least it works for me.
TINA looks at GLEN sharply.  He kisses NANCY and darts of class.
Hey!  You have a nightmare too?
But GLEN's gone.
Maybe we're gonna have the Big Earthquake.  They say things get weird just before that...
BELLS ARE RINGING, and STUDENTS crowding; TINA and NANCY drawn into the crush.

ANGLE ON A MODEST HOME; no car, just a couple of BIKES in drive.  Every light in the house and yard is turned on. the rock group MADNESS played at a 'No adults home' volum 9.    INT.  TINA'S LIVING ROOM.  NIGHT. ON GLEN, dialing.  Nancy and TINA are watching, giggling.
I can't believe his mother let him come over here.
Right.  Well, she didn't, exactly...
GLEN shoves a cassette into TINA's Ghetto Blaster.
(to TINA) See, I got this cousin who lives near the airport, that it's okay for me to stay with, right?  So I found this sound effects tape at Licorice Pizza, and...
The phone is answered.  GLEN jerks the tone arm off the r with a SCRUUPT!!
Hello, Mom? (pushes the 'play' button) Yeah, out here at Barry's.
A JET PLANE begins to make itself heard on the tape.  GLE the machine closer to the phone.  It's a big plane -- sou a 747 coming in for a landing.
Huh?  Yeah, noisy as usual.  Glad we don't live here -- huh?  Yeah, Aunt Eunice says hello.
The Jet is SCREAMING IN now, full flaps and howling like monstrous banshee.  NANCY and TINA dissolve into muffled giggles.
(shouting over the din) Right, right -- I'll call you in the morning!  Right!  Huh?  Yeah, sure, I, huh?...
Suddenly the tape goes silent.  GLEN blanches.  Next mome another ENGINE is heard, but this one is a FORD LOTUS scr by at 180 mph.
(reacting to his mother's reaction) Uh... some kid's drag racing outside, I think...

The sound effect changes abruptly to a SPEEDING SEDAN -- ages-old SCREECH of BRAKES, last-second SCREAM and horrib COLLISION.  NANCY gamely tries to find the right button t it off, but misses.  There's a loud SCREEK of fast-forwar -- Glen improvises desperately.
Listen, Mom, I got to go -- I think there's been an accident out front -- I --

NANCY jumps back from the cassette player -- WORLD WAR II out at top volume -- MACHINE GUNS, HAND GRENADES, DIVING and SHOUTS of charging Huns.  GLEN makes a last-ditch div flings the cassette out of the machine. Blessed silence at last.
Right.  I'll call the police.  No, just some neighbors having a fight, I guess.  I'm fine, I'm fine! Call you in the morning!
He hangs up and sags back.
Worked like a charm.
Jesus.

TINA shoves another cassette in, and MICHAEL JACKSON'S 'T blasts from the STEREO.  The kids relax, the CAMERA GLIDE THEM TO THE WINDOW. The WIND is moving the bare TREE BRANCH outside.  CAMERA BACK to the comfortably threadbare room, uneasy.  We see poking at a flame in the hearth as TINA comes FOREGROUND the drapes.
Nice to have a fire.
Really.  Turn 'er up a little.
NANCY turns a nearby valve handle, and the gas fire climb brightly over its artificial log.  TINA joins her, hearte
Maybe we should call Rod, have him come over too.  He might get jealous.
Rod and I are done.  He's too much of a maniac.
He should join the Marines, they could make something out of him. Like a hand grenade.
TINA laughs despite herself.  NANCY brightens.
See?  You've forgotten the bad dream.  Didn't I tell you?
TINA shakes her head, wishing she had forgotten.
All day long I been seeing that guy's weird face, and hearing those fingernails...
NANCY looks up with a flinch.
Fingernails? (blinks, laughing) That's amazing, you saying that. It made me remember the dream I had last night.
TINA looks up.
What you dream?

I dreamed about this guy in a dirty red and yellow sweater; I dream in color, y'know; he walked into the room I was in, right, right through the wall, like it was smoke or something, and just stared at me.  Sort of ...obscenely.  Then he walked out through the wall on the other side.  Like he'd just come to check me out...
The story has left the room deathly quiet.  Especially TI effected.
(quietly) So what about the fingernails?
NANCY remembers, imitating the frightful coincidence.
He scraped his fingernails along things -- actually, they were more like fingerknives or something, like he'd made them himself?  Anyway, they made this horrible nose -- (imitates)
sssssccrrrtttt .... TINA pales.
Nancy.  You dreamed about the same creep I did, Nancy...
The girls stare at each other.
That's impossible.
They look at him.  He looks away, as if suddenly listenin
What?
Nothing.
There's somebody out there,
isn't there...
I didn't hear anything...

Then there's an unmistakeable SOUND.  A distinct SCRAPING the house, just outside the window.  Something multiple, sharp.  Something like metal fingernails.  NANCY's mouth fraction of an inch. 10.   EXT.  FRONT OF HOUSE.  NIGHT. CLOSE ON FRONT DOOR as a BOLT UNLOCKS, a KEY TURNS, a CHA REMOVED.  At last the door swings open and GLEN swaggers
I'm gonna punch out your ugly lights, whoever you are.
No answer but a slight RUSTLE in the bushes.  GLEN does a walks right back inside.  The girls prod him right back o giddy with giggling fear.
It's just a stupid cat.
Then bring us back its tail and whiskers.
The girls push him farther.  GLEN edges towards the shado Then the SCRITCHING again.  GLEN stops; TINA edges back i house.
Anyway, I don't have a cat...
ANGLE INTO THE SHADOWS.  Turned from the girls, GLEN sobe listening.  IN HIS POV we see the street.  Silent houses. Motionless trees on empty lawns.
Kitty-kitty?  Chow chow chow?

Not a living, or dead, soul.  GLEN turns back to the girl shrug.  Instantly, a large FIGURE pounces and throws him ground with a shout. The girls SCREAM in panic and run for the house. 11.   REVERSE -- ROD leaps up and shouts like a sportscas
And it's number thirty-six, Rod Lane, bringing Lantz down just three yards from the goal with a brilliant tackle!  And the fans go wild!
ROD dances into the light, flashing a wild gypsy's grin a The girl's relieved and frightened at the same time.
What the hell you doing here?
Came to make up, no big deal. Your ma home?
Of course.  What's that?
ROD takes the spindly hand rake he's found and scraps the wall.  It makes a terrible SCRIIITCHING SOUND.  He grins tosses it aside.
Intense, huh? (sizes up the three) So what's happening, an orgy or something?
Maybe a funeral, you dickhead.
ROD wheels, a knife suddenly in his hand, as if ready to Glen's throat out.  NANCY breaks between --
-- Just a sleep-over date, Rod. Just Tina and me.  Glen was just leaving.
ROD eyes GLEN, laughs and flips the knife closed and away putting his arm around TINA's shoulder and laughing as if all a great joke.
You see his face? (lower) Your ma ain't home,
is she? (to Nancy & Glen) Me and Tina got stuff to discuss.
He pulls TINA inside without further ceremony.
Rod...
But ROD's already got himself and TINA halfway through th room, heading into the darker part of the house.
We got her mother's bed. You two got the rest.
We should get her out of here...
TINA darts to the front door, her blouse half out.
Hey -- you guys're hanging around -- right? (fake laughing/whine) Don't leave me alone with this lunatic -- Pleeeeze, NANCY!
She disappears.  GLEN looks at NANCY.  Too innocent.
So we'll guard her together. Through the night. (moving closer) In each others' arms like we always said.
Glen.  Not now.  I mean, we're here for Tina now, not for ourselves.
She kisses him lightly, then pushes him back.
(frustrated) Why's she so bothered by a stupid nightmare, anyway?
Because he was scary, that's why.
Who was scary?
NANCY turns and looks at him.
Don't you think it's weird, her and me dreaming about the same guy? (GLEN looks away; NANCY stares closer) You didn't have a bad dream last night, did you?
GLEN gives her a funny look.
Me?  I don't dream.
He takes her inside.  Over the SOUNDS of locks falling sh

FADE UP ON an old 50's CLOCK, one of those set into the b plaster body of a stalking panther.  It's just past 2 AM. PAN the cold hearth and darkened living room to REVEAL GL the couch, cacooned in sheets.  He's listening miserably SOUNDS OF LOVEMAKING coming from the next room.  TINA pea howls.  Then silence.
Morality sucks.

This is a slightly larger room than TINA's.  Adult.  Fema Spare in its appointments.  The streetlight throws the na into broken shadow and light.  TINA AND ROD lie in each o arms in the middle of the big bed.  Satiated.
I knew there was sometihng about you I liked...
ROD yawns into the pillows, happy.
You feel better now, right?
Jungle man fix Jane.
No more fights?
No more fights.
(sleepily) Good.  No more nightmares for either of us then.
He pulls the covers over his head.  He's almost out alrea
(beat) When did you have a nightmare?
(under the blankets) Guys can have nightmares too, y'know.  You ain't got a corner on the fucking market or something.
He rolls over, practically snoring, and pulls another cov his head.  A dirty red and yellow cover.
(sleepily) Where'd you get this snotty old thing?
SNORES from ROD.  TINA yawns, turns off the light and snu against ROD, pulling the cover gingerly over herself, too

CAMERA MOVES across the room of the original nightmare to NANCY alone in TINA's bed, staring at the slanting ceilin the bed.  Thinking.  We can just hear her HEART beating. sighs and turns on her side. Immediately the wall above her head turns a faint reddish with a broad yellow smear across its center.  All unseen NANCY, the wall begins to pulse in exact time with her he beat. CLOSE ON NANCY'S FACE.  She closes her eyes.

presses against the surface from the inside.  The plaster out as if suddenly elastic, taking the shape of the thing pressing from inside --  taking the shape of a man's face .  The face opens its mouth.  The knives rake through the surfac ANGLE ON NANCY -- as plaster dust snows down on her. She jerks awake, sitting bolt upright.  The face retracts suddenly -- the wall is normal. ANGLE DOWN ON NANCY as she looks up to the ceiling, touch hair and feeling the plaster dust. REVERSE IN HER POV TO THE CEILING.  There are three paral in the plaster there.  About eight inches long.  As if cu sharp knives.  Nothing else. Back on NANCY.  She draws the covers around her and shive Eyes wide open. 16.   EXT.  TINA'S HOUSE.  NIGHT. Not a car or person in sight.  A stricken breeze dies in trees. 17.   ZOOM IN on the window of the room where TINA sleeps we're FULL IN CLOSE on it, the air is again still as deat moment later a PEBBLE bounces off the pane.  The NIGHTMAR appears in the lower registers and holds its breath. Another PEBBLE strikes, with a sharper RAP. 18.   INT.  TINA'S MOTHER'S BEDROOM.  NIGHT. CLOSE ON TINA'S FACE as her eyes open. 19.   REVERSE IN HER POV.  Another PEBBLE clatters off th 20.   TINA raises slowly.
ROD...

SNORES FROM ROD.  TINA sits up. PAST HER TO THE WINDOW.  The WIND MOVES AGAIN; the trees the window with their shadows.  Then another pebble.  RAP slips to the window. 21.   EXT.  TINA'S BACKYARD.  NIGHT. She looks out on an old yard with a patch of bananna tree rattling in the Santa Ana winds.  It seems deserted, thou welling dark won't let her be sure.  Then another pebble -- hitting with a sharp RACK FOCUS. 22.   A LOW ANGLE TO WINDOW as TINA jumps back, startled. seen that one coming.  But she's drawn back to the glass curiousity, straining to see in the dark.  It's as if the are materializing out of thin air. 23.   INT.  TINA'S MOTHER'S ROOM.  NIGHT.
!  This time a heavier stone, and a thin crack bristles across the glass.
(low) Who the fuck you think you are, whoever you are?

head_text.subj: THE REAR OF THE HOUSE. A LIGHT COMES ON.

text: appears in the doorway.
(listening) Somebody there?
She can see through the backward to a yawning gate and th alley.  No one there.  But a word is spoken, as if by win
(garbled) Tina.
TINA straightens, unable to swallow.  There's a ragged, o GIGGLE.  Deep in the throat.  Phlegmy.
Who the hell

is that? TINA charges across the yard and through the gate, the MU chasing after. 25.   EXT.  A SERVICE ALLEY.  NIGHT. She brakes in the middle of the alley and whirls around. Listening.  Shivering in the same thin slashed nightgown. A sharp crank of METAL, and fifty feet down the alley the an ash can rolls from the dark like a huge tin coin and s noisily down. 26.   LOW REVERSE ACROSS LID TO TINA.  Despite herself sh and touches it.  She comes up with long worms on her fing Next moment the exact same shambling MAN from her nightma staggers into view fifty feet behind her.  TINA falls bac the shadows, shaking the worms off her fingers in repulsi MAN turns and starts directly for her, something shining right hand as he spreads his arms wide.  He starts scrapi steel FINGERNAILS along a cinderblock wall.  Orange spark out -- his arms elongate until they reach from one side o alley to the other -- and TINA is cut off from her home! CLOSE ON HER as the SCRAPING of the blades gets louder an closer.  She begins to shake uncontrollably.
Oh, shit, please God...
(softly, approaching)

This is God... He holds up his steel-tipped hand like a surgical-steel s TINA runs for her life. 27.   WIDER ANGLE IN THE ALLEY -- a terrifying, all-out f between the girl and her pursuer.  The MAN is fast; the d between them closes with each heartbeat.  TINA overturns -- claws her way through a rotten back fence, hammers aga window.  Ashen FACES appear, recoil, pull curtains closed disappear in fright. 28.   EXT.  TINA'S STREET.  NIGHT. TINA runs out onto front lawns, SCREAMING for help.  No h comes.  In fact, the only response is for all the porch l the block to be turned off.  The MAN roars out from behin -- a tree too narrow to have hidden him -- nearly upon th TINA runs in panic -- at last making her own home, only t trapped against its locked front door. She hammers against its thick wood.
Nancy!  Open the door -- Nancy!
The MAN slows.  He has TINA now and knows it.
She's still awake.  Nancy can't hear you.

TINA turns and looks full at the approaching MAN.  Smudge deep shadow, he's big and hideous.  He wears the same dir yellow sweater from the first nightmare -- from the wall- and blanket too -- and has the same sagging hat and leeri over his misshapen face.  And on his fingers are the stee talons. 29.   CLOSE ON HIM as he takes the blade on the end of hi finger and lopes off one of the fingers of his left hand. another.  We SEE the PIECES OF FINGERS fall past TINA'S f SLOW MOTION. ANGLE ON THE GROUND of the FINGERS squirming on the groun flopping onto TINA's naked foot. TINA leaps back, sickened, and begins stamping on then as were huge bugs. The MAN snaps up his arm and the FINGERS fly back into pl his hand.  He leers at TINA -- then suddenly lunges at he sweeping with his cutting hand! TINA's no weak sister -- blocks his arm, deflecting the s and grabs the MAN's ugly face with her other hand.   But the face only slides off to the bone .  The MAN presses in, and TINA contorts in horror as the knives slash across her shoulde cutting her deeply. 29A.  TINA staggers backward, GROANING, her foot now inex caught in bedclothes!  She falls over her bed's conformte away from the man and, like a child, pulls the cover over The skull-faced MAN crushes down, and there's a fierce gr -- punctuated by his GRUNTS and the girl's DEAFENING SCRE and they both become totally wrapped in the comforter -- they're beneath it, fighting for life and death. 30.   INT.  TINA'S BEDROOM.  NIGHT. ROD lurches up into CLOSE UP in the lightless bedroom, half-awakened by the tremendous struggle somewhere, someh inside the dark bed.  ROD grabs groggily, lifting the blanket. 30A.  IN HIS POV we glimpse the dark underside of the bla TWO SHADOWY FIGURES flailing and clawing under the bedspr TINA and the MAN -- or a shape that could be a man -- rag against each other. ROD drops the blanket and leaps from the bed, scared full and terrified.  Then the horrible TINA's GASPS change to CRIES of a terribly wounded victim.  ROD instantly jerks bedspread. IN HIS POV we SEE TINA struggling and flailing along on t sheets, the MAN nowhere in sight.
T-tina!?

Suddenly TINA -- eyes turned inward to her tormentor -- g awful jolt -- her arms and legs are spraddled as if by overwhelming force and pinned to the bed.  Next instant, nightgown flies apart and four long gashes chase across h torso.  From no visible instruments!  A huge irrigation o floods the bed. Terrified, ROD dives for the light -- but at the same mom something invisible grabs TINA, wielding her body in the bringing it around in a swift blow that knocks ROD crashi the light -- smashing it to bits. 31.   CLOSER ON HIM as he struggles around.  In the blue ELECTRICITY ROD sees TINA sliding  up the bedroom wall in a dark smear, dragged feet first

ANGLE ON ROD -- paralized by terror! ANGLE ON TINA'S DYING EYES -- moving with her up the wall bumping around the corner onto the ceiling.  She's just l at who's dragging her, eyes glazing. REVERSE IN HER POV -- to the shadowy, horrendously ugly M dragging her with fierce glee across the ceiling, literal swabbing the ceiling with her bloody body.  SEEN in FORCE PERSPECTIVE, the SHOT carries her across a great distance seeming to get anywhere -- as if the ceiling is an endles plane. ANGLE DOWN ON ROD -- on his hands and knees -- the lamp n him blurting blue SPARKS and STROBING the nightmare room. screaming up at TINA'S invisible tormentor.
What the hell's going ON here! Tina!

ANGLE ON TINA -- upside down, clawing at the hanging swag above her mother's dressing table -- desperate for some a But she's dragged away from it.  The lamp swings back, it gushing more SPARKS. CLOSER along the ceiling as TINA rakes a long furrow in t ceiling with her fingernails.  But her eyes are glazing, glazing.  And then they fall closed. WIDE, UP ON THE CEILING, as her body suddenly flops loose hanging for an awful moment by the feet over the bed. REVERSE ON ROD -- staring like a terrified child.
Tina --

REVERSE IN HIS POV -- as the body falls like a sack of ro the devastated bed, in SLOW MOTION, striking with a huge of blood.  A sick, awful GIGGLE floats around the room, t ECHOES off into infinity.  ROD staggers up, staring aroun hoping to see this phantom.
You motherfucker
I'll kill you for that!

NANCY is sitting straight up in bed, terrified.  The CRIE are ringing through the whole house.  She forces herself -- bolting from the bed despite her terror and sense of d 33.   INT.  HALLWAY.  NIGHT. NANCY flies into the dark hall -- crashing directly into who lurches out of the dark before her.  She SCREAMS and back --
What the hell's going on!?
Oh -- jeez -- Glen!  Rod's gone ape!
(sobbing) I'll kill you!
NANCY grabs the door; it's locked; she pounds on it.  BAM
Things fall into sudden, awful silence on the other side. voice cracks with fear.
Rod? (silence) Rod, you better not hurt Tina...

ROD erupts into terrible HOARSE LAUGHTER AND SOBBING.  Th hear BREAKING GLASS. GLEN barrels into the door like the football player he is frame splinters and they're in. 34.   INT.  TINA'S MOTHER'S BEDROOM.  NIGHT. Just inside the door NANCY slips and goes down hard.  GLE her in the dark more by touch than sight.
You okay?
Yeah.  Something slippering all over here... (feeling) Tina?

No answer.  The room is quiet as a tomb.  Except for a st DRIPPING, from all over.  Then GLEN finds a LIGHT SWITCH. On the CLICK the devastation is revealed.  There's BLOOD everywhere: up the walls, over the clawed ceiling, soakin killing floor of the bed, and pooling in the dark red pud where NANCY has slipped and fallen.
Oh, shit...
NANCY wobbles up and sees TINA in the center of the ravag Unmistakeably and utterly dead.  NANCY presses against th then contorts and chokes.
(numb) I...I'm gonna call the cops --
He bursts from the room. 35.   TIGHT ON NANCY.  She turns away from the body in re sticking her head through the shattered window ROD LANE u his escape, sucking in the cold night air and moaning.

FADE UP ON RED LIGHTS and SIREN as an unmarked POLICE CAR to the curb. LT DON THOMPSON, a decent-looking man in his mid-40's, ex punches a cigarette from his pack.  His shaken aide, a un patrolman named PARKER, greets him.  (CAMERA FOLLOWS them the car straight into the station and eventually to THOMP
Lieutenant Thompson.  Sorry to wake you, but --
I'd've canned your ass if you hadn't.  What you got?
PARKER stumbles to open the door for THOMPSON as the man into the station at a furious pace.
Her name was Tina Gray.  It was her home.  Father abandoned ten years ago, mother's in Vegas with a boyfriend.  We're trying to reach her now.
LT THOMPSON grimaces as if he knows the story.
What's the Coroner got to say?
Something like a razor was the weapon, but nothing found on the scene.
THOMPSON is already to the desk officer SERGEANT GARCIA. MAN shoves him a sheaf of papers --
(wary) Leautenant.  You know who --
Where is she?
I put her in your office...
PARKER scurries after.
Looks like her boyfriend did it.  Rod Lane.  Musician type, arrests for brawling, dope --

ANGLE ACROSS NANCY'S "TREE LAWN", the grass between the sidewalk and the street, in the general direction of GLEN's home.  This ANGLE doesn't quite reveal Nancy's house. FOREGROUND is a utility truck in which a half dozen Hispanic WORKERS are loading tools, extension cords and hardware.  They look like they've put in one hell of a hard day's work. MARGE appears and hands a check to the FOREMAN of the cre white guy in clean coveralls and a gold chain.  He scruti it.
And the other...
MARGE forks over a wad of cash, hands trembling in her half-drunk, helpless rage.
Where's your mask and gun?
The FOREMAN counts the money swiftly.
Don't bust my chops, lady. If the city found out I put 'em in without inside releases I'd loose my license.

He shoves the money in his pocket and climbs in his truck EXITS FRAME for her house. PAN WITH THE TRUCK as it pulls away, THEN PICK UP NANCY, across the street from the corner.  Alone.  Dispirited. lifts her eyes to her home and stops in her tracks.
Oh gross...

123.  WIDENING TO REVEAL THE HOUSE as NANCY walks across yard.   Every single window has been covered with brand-new ornamental iron bars, bolted deeply into their frames . CLOSER, AT A WINDOW.  NANCY gives a set of bars a powerfu shake.  They don't budge.  Then girl looks up and sees ev window to her second floor bedroom is barred.  And the ro trellis has been ripped down and heaped at the foundation tangle of wood, thorns and broken flowers. 124.  INT.  MARGE'S ROOM.  EVENING. ANGLE ON THE DOORWAY INTO THE HALL.  Easy listening MUSIC through the air.  NANCY appears in the doorway.
Mom, what's with the bars!?
125.  REVERSE to MARGE, propped against the headboard of crooked shadow in the gloom.  A fresh bottle of Gin glint hand.
Oh, Mom...
The girl crosses and reaches gently for the bottle.  MARG snatches it away.
'S'mine...
She rocks the bottle in her arms.
What's with the bars?
S'curity.
NANCY sits on the bed, a surprising compassion entering h voice.
Mom, I want to know what you know about Fred Krueger.
Dead and gone.
I want to know how, where -- if you don't tell me, I'm going to call daddy.
MARGE gives a laugh -- a rasping chachination from deep i chest.
Your father the cop.  That's a good one. (colder) Forget Fred Krueger.  You don't want to know, believe me.
I
do want to know.  He's  not dead and gone -- he's
after me and if I sleep he'll get me! I've got to know!
MARGE blinks at her a moment, then cracks a terrible, cro grin.
All right.
MARGE drags NANCY headlong down the cellar stairs and acr room with a crazy fury, twisting her down near the founda And she thrusts her face so close to her daughter's that reels from the alcohol.

You want to know who Fred Krueger was?  He was a filthy child killer who got at least twenty kids, kids from our area, kids we all knew.  It drove us all crazy when we didn't know who was doing it -- but it was even worse when they caught him.
MARGE draws herself up with a shake.
Oh lawyers got fat and the judge got famous, but someone forgot to sign the search warrant in the  right place, and Fred Krueger was free, just like that.
So he's alive?
MARGE smiles grimly.
He wouldn've stopped.  The  bastard would've got more kids first chance he got -- they found nearly ten bodies in his boiler room as it was.  But the law couldn't touch him.
At the mention of "boiler room", NANCY gives a shake.  MA misses this, too busy taking a pull on the bottle that's left her hand.
What was needed were some private citizens willing to do what had to be
done . She reels slowly, looking at NANCY is defiance.
(hushed) What did you do, mother?
MARGE cradles the bottle.

Bunch of us parents tracked him down after they let him go.  Found him in an old boiler room, just like before.  Saw him lying there in that caked red and yellow sweater he always wore, drunk an' asleep with his weird knives by his side...
(dreading it) Go on...
MARGE reaches over and taps a dusty two-gallon jug of gas near the lawn mower.
We poured gasoline all around the place, left a trail out the  door, locked the door, then...
She mimes striking a match --
WHOOSH!!!
Her arms shoot up and her eyes go wide with the light of fire.  There's awe in her voice.  Then she drops her arms

(hushed, remembering) But just when it seemed not even the devil could live in there any more -- he crashed out like a banshee, all on fire -- swinging those fingerknives every which direction and  screaming he... he was going to get us by killing all our kids...
She stops with a sudden quake and drinks for a long momen the intake doesn't hide the image.  Her face bathed in te looks at her daughter and shakes her head.

There were all those men, Nancy, even your father, oh yes, even him.  But none could do what had to be done -- Krueger rolling  and screaming so loud the whole state could hear -- no one could take your father's gun and kill  him good and proper except
me . She sweeps her hand across the air in a terrific slash, t stops, her hand shaking, her voice hoarse and terrified. looks at her daughter, begging.
So he's dead Nan.  He can't get you.  Mommy killed him.
For someone who started this film at a very young sevente NANCY's now the battle-tempered veteran as she takes her in her arms and rocks her.
Who was there?  Were Tina's  parents there?  Were Rod's?
MARGE sags back.
Sure, and Glen's.  All of us. But that's in the past now, baby.  Really.  It's over. (slyly) We even took his knives.

The woman twists around and opens the door on an old furn furnace unused since the newer gas one nearby was put in. fishes inside the cavity -- as then we hear a touch of th familiar 'SCRRIITCH'.  Next moment she pulls out an objec wrapped in rags, opens it and displays the long, rusted b and their glove-like apparatus.
See?
NANCY stares at the damn things, chilled.
All these years you've kept those things buried down here?  In our own house?
Proof he's declawed.  As for him, we buried him good and deep.
MARGE shoves the knives into their hiding place, closes t little iron door.
So's okay, you can sleep.

She lurches up and staggers upstairs. NANCY shivers and looks down at her arm.  The cut beneath bandage has begun to bleed again.  And from inside the fu as if from deep below, the PULSING of the boundless nightmare-boiler room can be faintly heard. 127.  EXT.  ELM STREET.  NIGHT. WIDE ON THE STREET AND BOTH HOUSES, GLEN's on the right, on the left.  A TELEPHONE RINGS.  ZOOM IN ON GLEN'S UPSTA BEDROOM WINDOW. 128.  INT.  GLEN'S & NANCY'S BEDROOMS - INTERCUT.  NIGHT. 129.  GLEN, yawning, crosses and picks up his telephone.
Hello? NANCY (telephone) Hi.
Oh.  Hi, how y'doing?
NANCY looks out the window and touches her hair.
Fine.  Stand by your window so I can see you.  You sound a million miles away.
In the lighted window across the way, she can SEE GLEN mo sight.  In his shot, we can SEE NANCY step into her windo the bars.
Much better.
I heard your ma went ape at the  security store today.  You look like the Prisoner of Zenda or something.  How long's it been  since you slept?
Coming up on the seventh day.  It's okay, I checked Guiness.  The  record's eleven, and I'll beat  that if I have to. (beat) Listen, I... I know who he is.
Who?
The killer.
You do?
Yeah, and if he gets me, I'm pretty sure you're next.
GLEN is appalled.
Me!?  Why would anyone want to kill me?!
Don't ask -- just give me some help nailing this guy when I bring him out.
GLEN pales.
Bring him out of what?
My dream.
How you plan to do that?
Just like I did the hat.  Have a hold of the sucker when you wake me up.
Me? (switching back to a more comfortable reality) Wait a minute, you can't bring someone out of a dream!
If I can't, then you all can relax, because it'll just be a simple case of me being nuts.
I can save you the trouble. You're nutty as a fruitcake. I love you anyway.
Good, then you won't mind cold-cocking this guy when I bring him out.
What
(simplicity itself) You heard me.  I grab him in the dream -- you see me struggling  so you wake me up.  We both come out, you cold cock the fucker, and we got him.  Clever, huh?
You crazy?  Hit him with what?
You're a jock.  You must have a baseball bat or something. Come to my window at midnight. And meanwhile...
(weakly) Meanwhile..?
Meanwhile whatever you do don't fall asleep.  Midnight.
She hangs up.  GLEN's eyes bug out.
Holy shit!  Midnight.  Baseball bats and boogemen.  Unfucking real.

HIGH, WIDE SHOT.  The moon is above the horizon.  A cool slides a bank of white fog inland.  The valley and its li stretch forever, an endless net of illumination and darkn coyote HOWLS on the dark hill. 132.  EXT.  POLICE STATION.  NIGHT. A palm frond scuttles across the center of the parking lo THOMPSON arrives in an unmarked car. COP (passing) Lieutenant Thompson -- what you doing in at this time?
Can't sleep, thought I'd come break up the poker game.
The COP laughs and goes his way.  THOMPSON's smile evapor 133.  INT.  POLICE STATION.  NIGHT. THOMPSON enters and checks the log.  Nearby, SGT GARCIA p coffee.
If it was any more quiet we could hear owls farting.
Is quiet, isn't it?
(too casually) How's your girl?
THOMPSON looks at the Desk sergeant a moment, then tosses the log.
She's sensible.  She'll sleep sooner or later.

The neighborhood is utterly still, most of the homes alre dark.  But not NANCY's.  Or GLEN's. ZOOM TO GLEN'S LIGHTED LIVING ROOM WINDOW. 135.  INT.  GLEN'S LIVING ROOM.  NIGHT. GLEN's father watches eleven o'clocks news, a dreary FILM (STOCK) of war and refugees in a far-away land. MR LANTZ takes a pull on his Bud.
You'd think they'd have
some- thing 'bout the Lane kid hanging himself.
MRS LANTZ walks through the room, drying her hands on a dishtowel.
Maybe we're all making more out of it than we should.
She heads upstairs.  MR LANTZ pops the automatic tuner. blinks ON.
I wouldn't touch that line with a ten foot pole.
ED MCMAHON and the AUDIENCE laugh in delight. 136.  INT.  GLEN'S HOUSE/UPSTAIRS CORRIDOR.  NIGHT. MRS LANTZ comes along the upstairs hall and knocks gently closed door.
Glen?  you all right?
She puts her ear to the door and listens.
Glen honey?

No answer. 137.  INT.  GLEN'S ROOM.  NIGHT. GLEN lies sprawled across the bed, long legs flung over t head not visible. His mother enters.  She looks at the boy, turns off the T From this angle she can see his head, earphones crammed o rasping their tinny noise.  But no movement from the kid MRS LANTZ crosses and pokes him in the ribs.  GLEN lurche arms windmilling.
Whuu?
He refocuses his eyes, takes off his earphones.
How can you listen to Carson and a record at the same time?
GLEN swings his legs over the edge of the bed and shakes to clear the cobwebs.
Wasn't listening to the tube, just watching.  Miss Nude America's supposed to be on tonight.
Well how you gonna hear what she says?
Who cares what she says?
The mother gives up.
You should get to sleep soon,  Glen.  It's almost midnight. Goodness knows we've all had enough of a time the last few days...
I will, Mom...in a while. You guys turning in?
Pretty soon.

His MOTHER sighs and goes out, closing the door behind he flips the TV back on and glances at the clock. 138.  INSERT OF CLOCK.  It's 11:42. 139.  TIGHT ON GLEN's face.  He clamps the earphones back the volume up high.  The MUSIC is so loud we can hear it resonating inside his skull. CAMERA MOVES PAST GLEN to his window, then ZOOMS through 140.  EXT.  ELM STREET / NANCY'S HOUSE.  NIGHT. CONTINUE ZOOMING into the LIGHTED window of NANCY's barre floor bedroom and
CLOSE ON MARGE, weaving on the edge of NANCY's bed, strok the girl's hair.  NANCY's still something of a wreck, but than         MARGE.
We'll go away, take a vacation. Get your hair colored nice, the way it was.  No one will ever know. (sniffs) This whole room smells of coffee, y'know?
She gathers up NANCY's coffee cups and empty NoDoz boxes, down and kisses her.
It's all over now, baby.  The nightmare's over.  Please.
NANCY nods her head, half stubborn, half sadly.  She can keep her eyes open now.
Okay.
She scrunches into her pillow.  MARGE smiles haggardly an off the light, taking the coffee pot with her as she leav
Night-night.

MARGE smiles, relieved.  The girl pulls the blanket aroun shoulders.  Her eyes flutter closed, her breathing become and deep.  Once again she's the litle girl MARGE fantasiz is. The mother tiptoes out of the room, closing the door behi HOLD ON NANCY's sleeping face as the DOOR CLOSES.  Her ey remain closed another beat, then open wide. She quietly jumps out of bed and shakes herself savagely scatter the sleep settling so quickly. Still in the dark, she fishes a full electric coffepot fr her bed and pours herself a fresh fix into a mug she digs beneath her pillow.  The face illuminated by the neon lig pot is set in absolute determination. NANCY drains the cup, then crosses to her closet, retriev pitcher of ice water from behind a heap of clothes and sp her eyes and the back of her neck.  That done she eases o window and presses her face to the bars, sucking in cool air until every shred of sleep is gone from her brain. Then she starts pulling on clothes. 142.  INT.  NANCY'S HOUSE/DOWNSTAIRS.  NIGHT. ANGLE ON MARGE as she checks the lock on the backdoor.  F 143.  ANGLE IN THE LIVING ROOM as she pads through the da feels her way to a wall of shelves and takes down a book. another, and a third.  Then reaches in and fishes out a b gin. 144.  EXT.  NANCY'S HOUSE AND ELM STREET.  NIGHT. The sky has gathered in greater darkness.  LOW, DISTANT T rolls around the horizon like a great drum. ANGLE ON NANCY'S HOUSE from across the street.  The moon off the barred windows. CAMERA ZOOMS to NANCY's window. imprisoned girl hovers in the darkness behind the grill l ghost, her eyes turned towards GLEN's.  Then she switches something much CLOSER TO CAMERA ANGLE, and she draws back 145.  REVERSE ON GLEN's father, standing on the front por home, also in the shadows, looking straight across and up NANCY.  He         draws on his cigarette; his face glows 146.  NANCY pulls down the shade. 147.  GLEN's father grinds the cigarette beneath his shoe
Shouldn't stare.
As the man turns our SHOT WIDENS TO REVEAL MRS LANTZ.
Know what I think?  I think  that kid's some kinda lunatic.
The woman spoons more sweetness into her mouth and rubs h forehead.
Shouldn't say such a thing about the poor child.  If you mean the  bars, Marge's just being cautious, her being alone and Nancy acting so nervous lately.
The woman rises and pulls him gently towards the living r he goes inside he takes one last look.
Well, she ain't gonna hang around our boy no more.

Once the two are inside, the door is locked. 148.  INT.  NANCY'S ROOM.  NIGHT. CLOSE ON NANCY's face.  VERY CLOSE.  Her eyes stare ahead red-rimmed, anxious.  She picks absently at the thick ban covering her forearm.  The long cuts from Fred Krueger's are bleeding again, but she doesn't even care anymore.  T to sweat the small stuff.  She crosses the room. On the bedside table with the nearly empty Pyrex coffee m the empty cup and the empty box of No-Doz, is her old fas alarm clock, and a phone. NANCY pours herself the last of the coffee and drinks it dregs, then looks to the clock. INSERT CLOCK -- ten minutes to midnight. NANCY'S eyes go to the door. WIDER.  Fully clothed and in a jacket now, she creeps to and cracks it, just to make sure.  Then freezes. 149.  INT.  HALLWAY OUTSIDE NANCY'S DOOR. IN NANCY'S POV through the door we see MARGE, rummaging a the linen closet not fifteen feet away.  There's no way N get past her.  The woman pulls out a full bottle of gin i satisfaction and begins fumbling with its cap. 150.  INT.  NANCY'S ROOM.  NIGHT. NANCY eases the door closed again and sinks to the key ho watching through it with a sinking heart.
(very quiet, very intense) Hang on GLEN...

GLEN, coat now on, goes to his window, checking. 152.  INT.  ELM STREET.  NIGHT. GLEN'S POV -- NANCY'S porch is deserted; front door close lights out.  No sign of NANCY. 153.  INT.  GLEN'S ROOM.  NIGHT. GLEN shrugs, takes off his jacket and plops back onto his
Well, I'm not gonna risk sneaking out until she does.

He puts the earphones back on. 154.  INT.  NANCY'S ROOM.  NIGHT. Absolutely frustrated, NANCY turns from the keyhole to th window. She opens the blind and eases back the curtain. 155.  EXT.  ELM STREET.  NIGHT. IN NANCY'S POV THROUGH THE BARS we ZOOM directly across t window. 156.  INT.  GLEN'S ROOM.  NIGHT. GLEN lies on his bed, fully clothed, earphones over his e CARSON droning from the TV.  And the boy's eyes begin to 157.  INT.  NANCY'S BEDROOM.  NIGHT. NANCY picks up her phone, bites her lip, then begins dial 158.  INT.  GLEN'S ROOM.  NIGHT. TIGHT ON PHONE as it begins RINGING loudly. WIDER SHOT, revealing GLEN asleep BACKGROUND, the MUSIC s LOUD in his earphones. 159.  INT.  GLEN'S LIVING ROOM.  NIGHT. RINGING here, too, just as MR LANTZ is turning out the li bed.  He stops in the dark, scowling.
Who at this hour?
He refuses to turn the light back on.  His wife picks her the telephone.
Hello? (listens, frowns slightly) Oh... Hold on. (covers the mouthpiece) It's
her .  She wants to talk to Glen.
The father crosses to the telephone, suspicious.
(whispering) About what?
(into phone) What's this about, Nancy?
She listens, covers up again.
She says it's private.  Very  private and very important.
MR LANTZ grabs the telephone from his wife and barks into
Glen's asleep.  Talk to him tomorrow!
He SLAMS down the telephone with a grunt of satisfaction wife.
Just got to be firm with kids, is all.

Then as a refinement he takes the phone off the hook and on the table. 160.  INT.  NANCY'S ROOM.  NIGHT. NANCY dials again.  This time she gets a BUSY SIGNAL.  Sh the phone down in frustration and looks out the window.
Glen.
Don't fall asleep... She goes and sits on the bed, propping her chin on her fi 161.  Yawns.  The TELEPHONE RINGS. NANCY snatches it up.
Glen?

we HEAR the awful SCRITCHING SCRAPE of STEEL FINGERKNIVES NANCY slaps the phone down as if it were diseased -- then pure rage, rips the thing's cord from the wall. Spent instantly, she puts the receiver back on the cradle lays it on her bed, chiding herself.
Brilliant.  Now what if Glen calls?

She wraps the phone cord around the useless machine and p on her bed, then sneaks back to the door.  This time she expression of relief, and opens the door.  MARGE is gone. Then the TELEPHONE RINGS again. CAMERA MOVES IN ON NANCY as she turns slowly. 162.  REVERSE IN HER POV.  THE TELEPHONE RINGS again, des that the end of its janked-out cord is clearly visible. NIGHTMARE MUSIC THEME slips right up our spines. BACK ON NANCY.  She starts to shake.  She goes to the tel as we WIDEN, unwraps it as it RINGS even louder.  She's s so hard by now she can barely manage to lift the receiver IN CLOSE ON HER, so close we can HEAR her teeth chatterin brings the phone to her ear.
Hello?
The unmistakeable VOICE of FRED KRUEGER comes over the ph garbled by time and unknown dimensions, but clear enough.
(triumphant) I'm your boyfriend now...
It's changed from a normal telephone mouthpiece to an actual mouth
Fred Krueger's mouth
and his long, slick tongue flicks out and darts into the startled mouth

WIDER -- as NANCY explodes from her micro-dream -- absolu mad.  She jerks the telephone away from her and smashes i against her wall, then attacks it with her feet and hands smashing it to smithereens. ANGLE ON THE TELEPHONE PIECES.  Normal pieces of a normal telephone. She pinches herself hard -- until tears come and her fles nearly bleeding.
I'm awake, I am awake.  This is not a dream!  I am --
She stops, realizing what Krueger meant.
My boyfriend...!

NANCY barrels down the stairs and across the darkened liv to the front door. It takes her a moment of tugging and fumbling to realize deadbolt is locked from inside.  And there's no key in it She races to a porch window and throws it open, shaking a banging on the bars like a mad woman.  But there's no get through.  She staggers back, stymied and furious.  Then s moves behind her in the dark.
Locked.
NANCY jumps around in shock.  Her mother has posted herse the couch with her bottle.
(furious) Give me the key, mother.
I don't even have it on me, so forget it.
The word is final.  NANCY runs past the woman to the back to one window after the other, shaking bars and slamming and SCREAMING in teenage fury.  But it's no good.  The ho her prison.
(drunk satisfaction) Paid the guy damn good to make sure you stayed put.  You ain't goin' nowhere, kid.  You're gonna sleep tonight if it kills me.
NANCY clenches her fists and screams at the top of her lu heart-wrenching, eardrum-breaking cry of love in despair
GLEEENNNNNN!

CLOSE ON GLEN'S FROM DIRECTLY ABOVE.  The MUSIC is tinny earphones, the TV SOUND DISTANT AND ECHOED.  The boy is b deeply now, slowly and gently.  Then, unmistakeably, he b SNORE.  Very faintly, far in the background, we can hear
Glen!!  Don't fall asleeeeeep!

CAMERA PULLS BACK AND STRAIGHT UP as the SNORES merge wit weird, unsettling MUSIC CUE.  The boy lies sprawled, stil clothed, in the middle of his bed.  Save for the bedside the room is dark. FULL WIDE ANGLE FROM THIS HIGH SPOT looking down at him a the eyes of some great fly hung on the ceiling.  THE MUSI

head_text.subj: REACHES A TERRIFYING PITCH OF ANTICIPATION

text: There's a heartbeat's pause.  Then with tremendous force, powerful arms shoot up beneath the red and yellow bedspre grab GLEN around the waist! Next moment the young man's body is dragged straight down the bed, as if some huge beast had grabbed him and heaved down!  His feet and his arms shoot up -- there's another yank -- and the boy disappears except for his hands and f -- down into the pit in the middle of the bed!  His hands last to go, clawing for a hold.  But soon they vanish as dragging blankets and bedsheets, wires and stereo across caved-in bed and into the abyss. There's HIDEOUS SCREECHING of MUSIC jamming in with GLEN' ECHOING SCREAMS -- then an unholy, sudden silence. Next moment what's left of GLEN is vomited up from the pi nightmare bed...a horrible mess of blood and bone and hai wires...streaming out and over the bed.  Then the pit in is gone as if it were never there. Drawn by the terribly screams and struggle, GLEN's mother into the room.  The women stares for one moment of horrif disbelief, then reels back and lets out the most god-awfu imaginable.  The cry splits the night. 165.  EXT.  ELM STREET.  NIGHT. The SOUND of the SCREAM CROSS-FADES WITH the WAIL of the AMBULANCE as it screeches to a halt at the curb, followed BLACK AND WHITES and an UNMARKED CAR.  Uniformed POLICEME out FOREGROUND. LT THOMPSON and PARKER exit the unmarked car.  By habit o premonition THOMPSON glances at the house that was his ho eye is caught by a movement; his daughter is at her upsta window, white-haired, hollow-eyed, looking down on him th her bars.  She gives a little wave. Unnerved, THOMPSON waves back, then walks rapidly for GLE home.  MR LANTZ, pale as a ghost himself, waits on the po can hear the mother's WAILING inside. 166.  INT.  NANCY'S ROOM.  NIGHT. CLOSE ON NANCY'S BIG OLD WINDUP ALARM CLOCK.  Its big and hands sweep together at midnight.

There's a BABBLE of POLICE RADIOS, SIRENS WINDING DOWN, R FOOT-STEPS, SHOUTS, NEIGHBORHOOD KIDS and DOGS BARKING as LIFTS TO NANCY'S FACE.  Set.  Unafraid.  Ruthless. The girl pulls the window shade on it all, then looks at bed.
Okay, Krueger, you bastard. We play in your court.

168.  LT THOMPSON is halfway across the living room when Something dark and red is welling from a crack in the cei One of his men is rigging a bucket beneah to catch the le The telephone rings and PARKER picks it up.
Lieutenant.  It's your daughter. Says it's urgent.
THOMPSON turns away from the dripping.
(low) Tell her I'm not here, tell her...
Uh, she just saw you, sir...
THOMPSON nods, crosses and picks up the telephone.  SCREE SPLITS; we see both.
Hello Nancy.
Hi daddy.  I know what happened.
Then you know more than I do -- I haven't even been upstairs.
(guessing) You know he's dead though, right?
THOMPSON debates, then admits it.
Yeah, apparantly he's dead. How the hell'd you know?
A tear coarses down NANCY's cheek, but her voice remains
I've got a proposition for you.  Listen very carefully, please.
Nan, I --
Please.  I'm gonna go get the guy who did it and bring him to you.  I just need you be right there to arrest him. Okay?
Just tell me who did it and I'll go get him, baby.
Fred Krueger did it, Daddy, and only I can get him.  It's my nightmare he comes to.
The detective flinches at the name.
Where'd you hear about Krueger --
NANCY presses, very firm, very rational.
-- I want you to come over here and break the door down exactly twenty minutes from now -- can  you do that?
Sure, but...
That'll be exactly half past  midnight.  Time for me to fall asleep and find him.
Sure, sure, honey.  You just  do that -- get yourself some  sleep -- that's what I've been saying all along.
And you'll be here to catch him, right?
Lieutenant -- they're waiting upstairs.
THOMPSON waves curtly, still speaking to NANCY.
Sure, okay, I'll be there. Now you just turn in and get some rest, sweetheart.  Please. Deal?
Deal.
NANCY hangs up.  LT THOMPSON starts upstairs.  But then h and as an afterthought he could never really explain, tur PARKER.
Get outside and watch her house. If you see anything funny call me.
'Anything funny' like what?
THOMPSON shakes his head, embarassed.
I don't know -- but one thing for sure, I don't want her  coming over here.  She's way  too far gone to be able to to handle this.

As PARKER exits, ANGLE CUTS TO NANCY'S KITCHEN as the gir up and sinks back agiainst the wall, trapped by her own resolution.  She looks at her watch. 169.  INSERT -- five past midnight.  NANCY switches modes and sets the COUNTDOWN going at twenty-five minutes. 170.  INT.  GLEN'S BEDROOM.  NIGHT. LT THOMPSON steps into GLEN's room, anxious to be done wi He hits a wall of stench and horror even before he takes with his eyes, and as soon as he sees the bed he claps hi over his mouth, pivots and walks right back into the hall 171.  INT.  HALLWAY.  NIGHT. He sags against the wall, unable to look at the COPS who there.
(faint) What the hell did that, Lieutenant?  There ain't even a head left.
Goddamed if I know. (tries to straighten) What's the Coronor say?
He's in the john puking since  he saw it.

NANCY pulls tools and hardware out with grim resolution. nails, spools of wire, an old square of heavy fishneting, old shot gun shells, a file -- referring only once to the in her hand. 173.  INT.  NANCY'S LIVING ROOM.  NIGHT. Barely able to control her shaking hands, NANCY starts st off the spool of wire across the living room, crying and at the same time. DISSOLVE TO HER HANDS wrapping bare lamp wire around two thumbtacks stuck into the insides of the pinchers of a co wooden clothespin.  The wire goes OFF SCREEN.
